transcript.transcript: So when I came to New York in the 30s, I found the theater. Uh, to be. Uh, very difficult to make, make a living. There was a depression just starting, and the theater, um, suffered perhaps more quickly than other areas. Felt the depression. Um. I went around looking for jobs, and I was. Not only was it a question of of the competition involved, I mean, 1000 to 1, etcetera, but it was also the way in which they functioned as, uh. And casting the rather, uh, mass method of casting that occurred. I remember an experience I had with Theatre Guild in which they cast you. They they they wanted, uh, some they wanted some Frenchmen for a French play. Uh, and they wanted this was a play, I think, for size. Something about the miracle of Versailles or something. I don't remember the title exactly, but. I could have been done. I'm not sure. Um, anyway, they wanted these Frenchmen in the. I think there was a meeting with various countries, and they had representatives of various countries there, and and what they did was they they'd ask us to come to a To a cast. There was a casting call, I believe, about 100 people in the room, and they line all these people up in a row according to height. They say, turn around and you turn around, and then they say, go home. And then they send you another telegram a week later and say, come back and be 50 people in there. And they do the same thing and they say, go home and you get a third telegram. I came back the third time. It was about 12 or 12, 10 or 12 people in the room. They did the same thing. I didn't read any lines or anything. Well, I mean, after a little treatment like that about casting, they said, oh, what the hell is this? You know, what are you what are you what am I searching for here? So? So the Off-Broadway became the thing to do. I mean, in that period, the Off-Broadway not only was off Broadway, it was off. It was a social theater. The social theater was all there was. Our problem is because of the depression, because there was very little opportunity to do anything, and because the period was such that on all the intellectuals, most of the intellectuals at that time were involved in trying to do something about improving the society somehow. It was it was difficult for everyone. The bread lines, everyone was considered to be radical because the bread lines were long and everyone was very, very much involved. It was there was nothing like there is today where we're living in a prosperous era. Uh, so as a result, I began searching. I met other people who felt the same way, and we started trying to do something Off-Broadway. And I, I, uh. I chose a play that I was interested in, and I tried to get a production of it going, and it was called gaslighting by psychopaths, I think. And, um, uh, that fold that didn't get, didn't get done. But out of that, uh, a group of 4 or 5 of us remained and added to it, and we began trying to develop a kind of a, uh, theater, social theater. Um, and, uh, yeah, there's so much, I tell you the truth, you know, for me to try to get a a kind of a, I try to get a kind of a continuity of some kind. At that time, I'd have to really struggle like mad, you know? So. But it's pretty difficult for me to think that way. I mean, if I'm not asking for that, right. It's available, I think. I mean, record. Yeah. Uh. Well, what I would like. To get a sense of is to what extent did. A theater aesthetic and a sense of of political or social commitment. To what extent that carried over in the federal theater or the federal theater work against that? In other words, when the. Jungle first. Stopped and grew up here in, as I understand it more or less. Then went into the Federal Theater and try and stay. Yeah, right. Right. Right. And worked with the miser and great Catherine. Right. Um, was there a carryover or was that and or was there a continuity? What kind? So how? Many people. Did you speak to Van Barneveld? No I haven't. He's in Wisconsin, written in the number of times. He's working on an Ma in theatre history and writing. Yeah, so I'm here. Well, that's pretty damn nice. I have my ma, by the way, in case I got that over here in Florida. Florida. Atlantic. So I was teaching theater and I had no problem. I was teaching for my Ma. It's a nice way to do it. Yeah, right. I was fine. But, you know, all these people. Oh, this is, uh. Yes, I remember her now. Damn. I can't remember her name. Damn. Cool. No, this is Anne Gold. This is Perry. Ben. That looks like Jerry Williams a little bit, but I'm not sure. Yes or no? Uh. And that's where Lee, I guess, huh? I don't remember that. This gal I remember, I forgot her name. Oh, oh, oh, I know who that is. That's that's Kirk Conway. Yes, that's Conway, right. And this picture, I can see where he is now. This guy disappeared. I don't know who that is. And I played this part myself. Personally. It's been. Yeah. Now, this was. Great, Catherine. Well, this is a great Catherine. It was done on the same bill. Was it. Mhm. Mhm. And there was a. Well what's his name directed that this was done. And Maurice Clarke did a third one. Did Maurice do that. Oh Maurice Clarke did the third grade snickering horses. Right. And Joe Biden and Joe Biden there was a character. Boy he's no longer alive. But I went to see him once and like, you're going to see me. You know, I went to see him in New York, and he was already like, um, he was a. Very bitter radical of the before the 30 period. Before the 30 period, you know, in the 20s saying that period when they had, they had Mike Gold and Joe Bash and several other people. They had the theater of some kind. Yeah. And two of them, John Howard Lawson. And John Howard Lawson. Right. There's a total of five. Yeah. Well, why did you choose those plays? What were you what were you trying to do? That's a stupid question. I don't know what the hell is. I mean, I was it was just a matter of, um. The theater is a strange animal. Um. Well, I always thought that the Moliere play. I, uh, we were trying to do things that still had validity. And Moliere play multiplayer has quite a bit of a social document, and I guess each in his way. Each of the others is, I see. I didn't even remember that the one I experimental theatre was it. Actually, it must have been a mixture of, uh. Of the two theatres, the Theatre collective and the Theatre of Action. Because if Maurice and, uh. Did you did you talk to Brett at all? Brett. Warren? No. Is he alive? Yeah. I would very much like to, uh. I haven't been able to find out. Well, he's not well. He's not well, he has Parkinson's. And the last time I saw him, I tried to find him in New York, and I couldn't locate him, but, I don't know, I always got the feeling that I was just missing him or something, but that he was just. I didn't, I didn't. Would you like some more? No, I didn't hear that. Uh. He was. He was gone yet? So I think he's still there. I don't know. I don't know that he's not. Excuse me. Well, I think we were after the younger first. I mean, I was moving much more in the direction of the kind of things the Group Theatre was doing. It had to do with them having been involved in, um. Having been involved in theatre, which. Uh, which is which. I don't know how to express this, um, strongly social which which which was highly Experimental, which made no effort to come to grips with the realities of of the ordinary realistic life of a of a working man, but rather used chants, recitations, mass movements, and very arbitrary ways merely, you know, to make your point, which is a fine way of doing theater. But I found myself, uh, moving much more in the direction of the effort to try to deal with human beings on a real scale rather than on a, on a what you would like scale, you know, on a scale of where you, you point and this is what you do, because this is the point you want to make. And rather than do that, I prefer to I became involved in the process of really trying to relate acting wise to to something on a real level, and as a result, I mean, the influence of the Group theatre was very strong with us. And I think the process of growing up after a while, you just can't repeat that same kind of that same kind of, um, uh, thing, unless it's all right for certain kinds of actors. Possibly. I don't know. As a matter of fact, there are theatres that have stayed like that. You know, they have. I think some of the bigger theatres, there are big theatres that have existed like that. But for me, I found myself moving in the direction of psychological drama. And when we got onto federal theatre, there wasn't any possibility for us doing the kind of things we had done previously. We had to do things that had more, much broader appeal. And, uh, so I think for that reason, uh, Moliere was an acceptable vehicle. It was a classic. And I think in a sense, the great Catherine, which is an acceptable play Because it's short. It's short. So certainly there was nothing, uh, nothing for anyone to worry about in those terms. But of course, the theater that the whole setup and WPA was really did not move us away from, from a social direction. They were working and they worked toward a social direction. As a matter of fact, after a while, I was I don't think you want to experimental didn't stay long and I moved with the I was assistant director with Lem Ward on One Third of a nation. And as there's an example of of the kind of thing that we did on a smaller scale in the theater of action and done on a on a high scale there, and it becomes a fine piece of theater and very valid. As a matter of fact, I believe that that that kind of theater, there's, you know, there's real need for that kind of theater in our in with us all the time. So how would you compare? Can you give me a better. How would I. Compare of how? One third of a nation is enlarge what you were doing for small. Well, one third of a nation was a short, a short historical sketch of in play form. It was a kind of a it was a history of the growth of the United States. Um, it showed, uh, how how land became important. I mean, it's like, for instance, there was a scene or how, for instance, how, um, they had one scene on stage and they combined this with. All sorts of documents of the time, You know how. Who has who owns the land, how Trinity Church got its, got control of the land in Harlem, you know, or in various parts of New York and who was given grants and and you saw you saw how the land was given away. You saw how New York grew up. They had a scene where they brought they had just green grass, a little little spot of green grass you see out here. And then one person came out and he bought this little section from there was a man there, and he sold him a little section, and he stood on that section. He bought this little section. He stood there. Pretty soon there were there were people in this section, and this guy would take out a razor and start shaving. This one was doing something. There were about 12 people. First there was one person, pretty soon another one and a third and fourth one. And before you knew it, you know you had a microcosm of a whole city. And you saw in that little bit, you saw how the whole how the how New York City all of a sudden became how thousands of people came to this session and what happened as a result. It was a fantastic production that a third of a nation that kind of that kind of production that had the same thing with the it was they really what they did was it was a social document showing very clearly how all the thievery that has gone into land grabbing and much of the and much of the, uh, the manner in which legislation has maintained that thievery and held on to it. I mean, it was and in, in uh, there were a couple of other, um. Uh, living newspaper shows that had the same kind of it cut through it, cut through everything, you know, I mean, like, Brett Warren did a production on, um, electricity. The hell is that? Clock tower, right? It has a powerful show that cut through all the things and showed what was going on beneath it. And of course, they had a slew of writers working on it at the time. I mean, the guy. Do you remember the name of the man? Arthur rank? Yeah, right. Yeah. Arthur Aaron was was the head of a group of reporters who went out and got all the material together, and they all of it had social direction. All of it was an effort to try to to give a much deeper understanding of and a more truthful understanding of how all these things came into being. And I think it was very it was a very powerful period, very stimulating. Of course, the WPA itself was was a tremendous thing, I think. Perhaps if I dug into it and all of a sudden, because I had that experience recently. How in the hell all of a sudden that one experimental just was gone. All I can say is, I do remember. No, wait. I do remember that we had. Whether it was due to the social. The fact that we were the theater, we had been theater of action and theater collected, you know, whether it was due to the fact that what what came out in that first bill maybe was not that good, you know, maybe, maybe theatrically it wasn't that successful. Americano, I think, is still somewhere in New York. I don't know where. I imagine she's still in New York. Okay, um, how about Jack Renick? And was that the same Jack Renick? I think when we went and got involved in. I'm not sure. I must say. I'm not sure about this. I vaguely, I think at one point when we were involved in the theater of action started growing. I'm not sure I really I tell you, the thing is too vague. I'm not I'm not clear at all about because there were problems, because I remember I remember being involved with Jack And I remember some emotional problems because I know now I don't like Jack Renick that I know. That stuff. What did you expect? You expect the whole thing to open up the history to be shown? The hell with that bullshit. I can only give you what I have. Period. That's about all. Jack. Renick. Yeah, I know there's always politics. That's one of the things about the theater. You know, the politics are bad. Somebody is always trying to get somebody else's position or no power. The power struggle goes on there all the time. It's bad. I've seen him in many ways. New York was probably freer than I've talked to people in, uh, uh, that were in outlying areas Tampa, Atlanta, uh, and the smaller groups, it seemed to me the, the jealousies and the political problems were or at least more intense, if not worse, Really miserable. And I know. Well, maybe that's because I think in New York it's more you accept it more, perhaps they accept it more. You know, you you say, you say, well, it's highly competitive. I think the smaller towns still have that feeling that, um, possibly that they're, um. They're not willing to look at the realities of what the theater really is like. They the dream is there, but not the reality is more hidden in New York. The reality is more is more in the open. So you face it more. I don't know if that's possible or not. Let me ask two large questions. One of them the corollaries, one is do you think the Federal Theater did any good? Oh, yes. I think it was a great. In what ways? Well, I mean, the Federal Theater was like. Culturally speaking. There was there was a theater in every state which was state subsidized. That meant the development of actors, the development of playwrights, especially playwrights. It meant that all those theaters had to have plays, and there would be a search for those plays and the stimulation and the search and the and the chance to get those plays produced. And of course, it would. It would once you started with one art, you're involved in all the arts. I mean, the theater has, has dancing in it. It has, you know, choreographers. It has you're involved with with with all the arts designing sets. So, I mean, you're, uh, I mean, as far as I'm concerned, especially under Flanagan. I mean, Flanagan had a point of view. I mean, one can You can take theatre and make it say what you have to say depending on where you are. If there's a lid on it, you can only say what the lid will allow you. And I think that the Federal Theatre was a very rich period and I would say my own, my own feeling about theatre, my own feeling about theatre. For me, the group theatre was a very important thing. My relationship to the group or what it meant, and next to the group theatre, the the next biggest influence on me was the Federal Theatre as far as value was concerned, as far as combining social direction and art. I think it's the greatest experiment we've ever had, and it's one of the finest. It's the greatest thing we can do. It's the thing we should be doing, really. I think. In a sense, what you just said is at least part of that was due to the leadership and planning. I think so, right? Part of it was due to the leadership. Part of it is due to the time. I mean, today, for instance, you find writers are not writing like Steinbeck. At that time, Steinbeck was, you know, was a top writer. And what Steinbeck had to say in Grapes of Wrath represented something the country needed now. Of course, that's I say, socially speaking, the country needed that kind of theater, that kind of an expression. And I think it needs it now, too. And it constantly needs it. I mean, the, the kind of things that are occurring, the pollution, the the madness, the complete chaos and and unplanned, all unplanned, the congestion that goes on with the automobiles and the and the the prices going up, The oil scandals and the and the. All those things that are happening today like that, Jesus Christ. I mean, that needs a federal theatre, that needs examination, that needs plays to be written about it to be done. I mean, it's it's it would be terrific if you could have it. I think it's fantastic. I don't think there's been a greater period in American theater than that. I don't give a shit what anyone else says. That's the way I feel. I feel about it very strongly that that was a powerful that was a powerful cultural and social period in American and American theater. Anything else you want to say? I don't remember. I'm sorry. I can't be more.

lines.line: # Struggles in New York Theater During the 1930s

> The speaker recounts their arrival in New York during the 1930s and the difficulties faced in the theater industry. The Great Depression had begun, severely impacting the theater scene with high competition and a mass casting process that was impersonal and discouraging. The speaker describes an experience with Theatre Guild's casting process for a French play, highlighting the challenges and frustrations that led them to explore Off-Broadway opportunities.

metadata.title: Struggles in New York Theater During the 1930s
metadata.synopsis: The speaker recounts their arrival in New York during the 1930s and the difficulties faced in the theater industry. The Great Depression had begun, severely impacting the theater scene with high competition and a mass casting process that was impersonal and discouraging. The speaker describes an experience with Theatre Guild's casting process for a French play, highlighting the challenges and frustrations that led them to explore Off-Broadway opportunities.

lines.line: # Shift to Off-Broadway and Social Theater

> Due to the challenges in mainstream theater, the speaker and others turned to Off-Broadway, focusing on social theater during a time when intellectuals sought to address societal issues through art. The speaker attempted to produce a play titled 'gaslighting by psychopaths' which ultimately was not realized, but this endeavor led to the formation of a small group committed to developing socially relevant theater.

metadata.title: Shift to Off-Broadway and Social Theater
metadata.synopsis: Due to the challenges in mainstream theater, the speaker and others turned to Off-Broadway, focusing on social theater during a time when intellectuals sought to address societal issues through art. The speaker attempted to produce a play titled 'gaslighting by psychopaths' which ultimately was not realized, but this endeavor led to the formation of a small group committed to developing socially relevant theater.

lines.line: > The speaker expresses frustration and difficulty in recalling specific details about their past theater projects, highlighting the challenges of memory and historical documentation. They discuss the limitations of their recollections and the complexities of the theater's political and social dynamics, which often influenced the trajectory of their career and projects.

metadata.title: Challenges in Recalling Theater Work
metadata.synopsis: The speaker expresses frustration and difficulty in recalling specific details about their past theater projects, highlighting the challenges of memory and historical documentation. They discuss the limitations of their recollections and the complexities of the theater's political and social dynamics, which often influenced the trajectory of their career and projects.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses their involvement in the Federal Theater, reflecting on its aesthetic and political commitments. They mention working with notable figures and the transition of various colleagues within the theater community. The Federal Theater provided a platform for addressing social issues through performances, which was seen as an extension of the social activism of the time.

metadata.title: Involvement in the Federal Theater
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses their involvement in the Federal Theater, reflecting on its aesthetic and political commitments. They mention working with notable figures and the transition of various colleagues within the theater community. The Federal Theater provided a platform for addressing social issues through performances, which was seen as an extension of the social activism of the time.

lines.line: # Closure and Legacy of the Federal Theater

> The speaker discusses the end of the Federal Theater project and its subsequent impact on American theater and culture. They reflect on specific productions like 'One Third of a Nation' and the controversial 'Medicine Show,' which faced political challenges from Congress. The closure of the Federal Theater marked the end of a significant era of socially engaged public theater in America.

metadata.title: Closure and Legacy of the Federal Theater

They reflect on specific productions like 'One Third of a Nation' and the controversial 'Medicine Show,' which faced political challenges from Congress. The closure of the Federal Theater marked the end of a significant era of socially engaged public theater in America.

children.text: # Struggles in New York Theater During the 1930s

> The speaker recounts their arrival in New York during the 1930s and the difficulties faced in the theater industry. The Great Depression had begun, severely impacting the theater scene with high competition and a mass casting process that was impersonal and discouraging. The speaker describes an experience with Theatre Guild's casting process for a French play, highlighting the challenges and frustrations that led them to explore Off-Broadway opportunities.
# Shift to Off-Broadway and Social Theater

> Due to the challenges in mainstream theater, the speaker and others turned to Off-Broadway, focusing on social theater during a time when intellectuals sought to address societal issues through art. The speaker attempted to produce a play titled 'gaslighting by psychopaths' which ultimately was not realized, but this endeavor led to the formation of a small group committed to developing socially relevant theater.

> The speaker expresses frustration and difficulty in recalling specific details about their past theater projects, highlighting the challenges of memory and historical documentation. They discuss the limitations of their recollections and the complexities of the theater's political and social dynamics, which often influenced the trajectory of their career and projects.

> The speaker discusses their involvement in the Federal Theater, reflecting on its aesthetic and political commitments. They mention working with notable figures and the transition of various colleagues within the theater community. The Federal Theater provided a platform for addressing social issues through performances, which was seen as an extension of the social activism of the time.
# Closure and Legacy of the Federal Theater

> The speaker discusses the end of the Federal Theater project and its subsequent impact on American theater and culture. They reflect on specific productions like 'One Third of a Nation' and the controversial 'Medicine Show,' which faced political challenges from Congress. The closure of the Federal Theater marked the end of a significant era of socially engaged public theater in America.
